company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_title: Great place to start, but if you care about your career, don't get comfy here
review_info: Apr 19, 2022 - OTC Derivatives Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: Great role to break your way into the world of finance. It is definitely what you make of it. You could use your time just to go through the motions, or you can use your time to sharpen other skills alongside and try to actively learn and network.
cons: The work can become very algorithmic and just button pushing when you get used to it. Pay is not worth the amount of work done. Work-life balance is terrible and there was no sign that there was going to be improvement.
advice: There is a severe need for automation. In addition, the tools and time to create them are difficult to get.  Position needs less finance majors, more people with programming skills. More pay as well.

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_info: Sep 11, 2008 - Senior Billing Clerk in Syracuse, NY
pros: Their tuition reimbursement program makes potential for personal growth significant.  There were many opportunities for training within my division.  The environment was also friendly and inviting and it made coming to work each day less of an unpleasurable experience than it could have been.
cons: The level of compensation was, and remains, woeful.  The bank does not appreciate it's talent and does not offer a competitive level of compensation.  Employees are treated as expendable.  Also, in my experience, the management group in my department did not treat each employee with fairness and respect.  Lastly, the competence level of the leadership team left much to be desired.
advice: I would suggest that management restructure their budget to incoporate competitive levels of pay for their employees.  And, frankly, they should all get on the same page and start making company decisions with care.

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_info: Aug 15, 2008 - Accounting Analyst in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are pretty nice and vacation days are a-plenty. Also most people don't work very late.
cons: Management is not supportive of the employees and treats its subordinates with disrespect. The department is severely understaffed and issues always arise due to the fact that there aren't enough people to complete the job yet no new people are being hired to help the situation. You are also not allowed for much downtime during work in our Finance department and any attempt to have a chat with a coworker or go out for a long lunch will be reprimanded and is considered unacceptable, you basically are expected to sit in your cubicle all day and not get up. The pay is also ver low and below national average.
advice: Senior management should concentrate their efforts on equality for all employees. There is a lot of favoritism and not everyone gets a fair chance. Also, they should consider paying more and allowing more flexibility in terms of working arrangements (i.e. telecommuting or flex-time for those who need it). They should also be more loose about people's work/life balance and employees should be encouraged to interact with each other and go out for lunch together, within reasonable boundaries.

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_title: Good Company To Work For, But Expect Some Disappointment
review_info: Jul 16, 2008 - Reporting Specialist in Everett, MA
pros: Good job security, co-worker camaraderie, decent options with benefits packages, better-than-average 401k/company match (was better pre-merger though), great breadth of class/tutorial sessions offered (however, what you get out of them is often times far from applicable/useful)
cons: Compensation/benefits meant to fall 'middle of the road' and rarely higher than median market value/trends; promotions/recognitions/raises seem to not always be performance related; annual raises average 2-4%, which barely covers cost of living off-set; work can be tedious at times, and opportunities to 'extend' duties rarely present themselves (stagnant workload growth)
advice: Get more involved with teams and individuals; have more sporadic recognitions of good work; try to create more of a enjoyable atmosphere

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_title: Government Job - Stable and you can hide...
review_info: Aug 21, 2008 - Managing Director in New York, NY
pros: If you are interested in a stable job and do not care about challenges than this place is for you.  Think of it as a government job and you are there to collect a pay check.
cons: Most managers are incompetent because they have been in the same job for 10+ years.   We used to have a word for employees who we called "Lifers" because they never experienced anything else.  We also called them "Bone Heads" because they were clueless.
advice: Replace them all and get new managers who are willing to take chances and who are not "lifers"

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_title: A force to be reckoned with in 10 years.
review_info: Jul 22, 2008 - Sales Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The company is on the rise to become one of the most exclusive places to work on wall st. The company is in the midst of implementating alot of diversity and employee related initiatives to promote growth, therefore, one would have the opportunity to be on the cusp of everything.
cons: The location and condition of the HQ One Wall St. The mentality of the senior people in place, within each of the business lines are a bit on the cast system side. Not enough internal netwokring or personal development , ex seminars with career coaches, roundtables with senior management.
advice: I would ask Senior Management to look at the reputation and leadership of our peers on Wall St. Some of these companies have people lining up to work for them. This is how BNY Mellon, should be. Are we preparing ourselves and putting everything in place to ensure that we are the type of firm that our rivals envy.

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_title: Still shaking things out during consolidation
review_info: Jul 11, 2008 - Vice President in Harrison, NY
pros: Because it's there?   But seriously, in traditional banking functions, it does a decent job in comparison with the competition *and* treats its employees reasonably well.
cons: Corporate culture is still shaking itself out as part of the merger.  There is still no "one bank" - it is still "us" versus "them", with people jockeying for political advantage for when things settle down post-consolidation.
advice: It's good to be open.  But don't let the numbers guide all decisions - some costs are not worth cutting if it means demoralizing an already overtaxed staff which has not gotten a break since well before the divestiture of the branch network.

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_title: MBAs from Prestigious Business Schools, We Gotta Place for You to Work!
review_info: Jul 7, 2008 - Senior Analyst in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Bigcompanyitis; you can hide here. Also, if you are a minority with an MBA from a prestigious business school, you'll make it here big time.
cons: Defacto hypocrisy: it's not a "Great Place to Work" and there is no work/life balance, unless you suscribe to work > life formula
advice: They need to learn more about themselves, and understand that they too have biases and faults that contribute to the dysfunction of the organization, as opposed to blaming "underlings". They also need to learn about the dysfunctions of their corporate culture and "cure" them before embarking on fad programs which they think will "cure" their ills.

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_info: Jul 5, 2008 - Mutual Fund Accountant in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity for somone right out of college.  It is a great place to start.  It teaches you a lot about financial services.  I learned things at BONY that I didn't learn in college.
cons: No room for advancement. Should only stay a maximum of 2 years.  After 2 years, you should look for a better opportunity.
advice: There needs to be more room for advancement within the firm. That is the only way to retain great talent.  Management should create better outlets for people to explore within the firm.

company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
name_glassdoor: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORP
review_title: Bank of New York underpaid and under challenged
review_info: Jul 3, 2008 - Portfolio Administrator in Brooklyn, NY
pros: If you are looking for a job where you do the bare minimum and collect a paycheck this is the ideal place to work.  Most of the people there are unmotivated and underachievers.  Everyone that works there complains about how little they are paid yet very few take the steps to leave.  As an initial job it ok cause you learn a lot and are exposed to various areas.  But if you stay more then 2 years you get very comfortable it becomes hard to leave.  The place changes you for the worst.
cons: Its is boring and you do not use your brain
advice: They should realize that they are never going to keep any talent there.  They need to change the way things are because a person who works really hard and the person that does the bear minimum are treated pretty much the same.  The person who works really hard gets an extra 2 percent at the end of the year.
